conclusion: Determine the propagation time of monochromatic light in the water polo.
Calculate the path length of the light in the water polo and use the speed of light to find the propagation time.
Light travels from point A to point B through the water polo with an angle of incidence i = 30°.
Path length of the light can be broken down into segments AO and OB.
Distance AO is the radius of the inner circle, which is R.
Distance OB is the radius of the outer circle minus the radius of the inner circle, which is 5R/3.
Snell's law: n1 sin i = n2 sin θ, where n1 and n2 are indices of refraction.
Index of refraction of water is approximately n = c/v, where c is speed of light in vacuum and v is speed of light in water.
Speed of light in water is v = c/n.
Path length in water is the hypotenuse of triangle formed by paths AO and OB.
Using law of cosines, path length s = sqrt((R)^2 + (5R/3)^2 - 2 * R * 5R/3 * cos(90° - i)).
Since cos(90° - i) = sin i = sin 30° = 1/2, s = sqrt(R^2 + 25R^2/9 - 5R^2/3) = sqrt(19R^2/9) = sqrt(19)R/3.
Substituting n = c/v and v = c/n, propagation time t = sqrt(19)R * n/3c.
